Literature Review: The COVID-19 pandemic, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, has highlighted the critical role of the immune system in determining the severity of disease outcomes. Among the immune responses, type I interferons (IFNs) have emerged as pivotal players in the defense against viral infections, including SARS-CoV-2. This literature review explores the mechanisms by which SARS-CoV-2 interferes with type I IFN responses, the genetic and autoantibody factors that predispose individuals to severe COVID-19, and the implications for treatment strategies. Genetic studies have identified inborn errors in TLR3- and TLR7-dependent type I IFN immunity as significant risk factors for critical COVID-19 pneumonia. These findings are supported by virological studies demonstrating that SARS-CoV-2 proteins can inhibit the induction of and response to type I IFNs, thereby facilitating viral replication and spread. Furthermore, the presence of preexisting autoantibodies against IFN-α and/or IFN-ω has been linked to severe disease outcomes, underscoring the importance of type I IFNs in controlling SARS-CoV-2 infection. Cellular studies and mouse models have provided mechanistic insights, showing that type I IFNs can limit SARS-CoV-2 replication both in vitro and in vivo. Conversely, the absence or reduction of type I IFN activity leads to uncontrolled viral growth and severe pneumonia. These observations suggest that insufficient type I IFN activity during the early stages of infection is a common mechanism underlying critical COVID-19 pneumonia. This review also discusses the potential therapeutic implications of these findings, including the use of exogenous type I IFNs and strategies to neutralize autoantibodies against type I IFNs. Future research directions are proposed, focusing on the identification of additional genetic and immunological factors that contribute to severe COVID-19 and the development of targeted therapies to enhance type I IFN responses. In conclusion, the interplay between SARS-CoV-2 and the type I IFN system is a critical determinant of COVID-19 severity, with significant implications for understanding disease pathogenesis and developing effective treatments.
